awd_abstract_narration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the CERN laboratory near Geneva, Switzerland. However, the Standard Model as it currently exists, leaves open many questions about the universe. These include why matter dominates over anti-matter in the Universe (CP violation), the values of the masses of the fundamental constituents of matter, the quarks and the leptons, the size of the mixings among the quarks, and separately among the leptons, and the properties of dark matter. Most explanations require the presence of new forces and the development of concepts that now constitute what we call physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM). This award supports research that addresses those questions that dominate BSM physics. The research will be carried out at the LHC, which is the premier High Energy Physics particle accelerator in the world and one of the foremost facilities for answering these BSM questions. 

The University of Cincinnati group is a collaboration member of LHCb, an experiment designed specifically to study the decays of hadrons containing b or c quarks at the LHC. A goal of LHCb is to identify new physics in nature by examining the properties of hadrons containing these quarks. New physics, or new forces, can be manifest by particles as yet to be discovered, whose presence would modify decay rates and CP violating asymmetries of the hadrons containing the b and c quarks, and thus allow new phenomena to be observed indirectly.
  
This award will allow the University of Cincinnati group to further its study of rare decays of such heavy quark systems. Such decays can provide a unique window into physics at an energy scale well beyond that accessible by explicit production of new particles at colliders. The Cincinnati group's emphasis will be on charm quark physics, in which the group has established expertise.  Any discovery of BSM physics would be a huge step forward in our understanding of the fundamental physics of the universe.  This award will also facilitate the group's participation in the LHCb detector upgrade, that will improve the overall ability of the experiment to fully exploit the LHC data recorded through the next decade.

The Cincinnati group has a strong companion education and outreach program focused on its QuarkNet Center and its conduct of Masterclasses.  Many students who join the research effort are introduced to and engaged in the excitement of the science through these programs and through the group's participation in the University's Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model  was confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC)  in 2012. Unfortunately, it is well-established that the Standard Model fails to address many of the most interesting questions in the field.  Most explanations require the presence of new forces and the development of concepts that now constitute what we call physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM).

The University of Cincinnati group supported by this award is a collaboration member of LHCb, an experiment designed specifically to study the decays of hadrons (strongly interacting particles) containing b or c quarks at the LHC. A goal of LHCb is to search for new physics in nature by examining the properties of hadrons containing these quarks. New physics, or new forces, can be manifested by particles as yet to be discovered, whose presence would modify decay rates and particle-antiparticle decay rate asymmetries of the hadrons containing the b and c quarks, and thus allow BSM physics to be observed indirectly. At the same time, most of the analyses we do will not discover BSM physics but will advance  knowledge and understanding of  SM physics.

During the course of this award, we studied SM physics and searched for BSM physics.  We completed three analyses. One has been published; one has been accepted for publication; the results of the third were reported at a conference in the summer of 2022 and have now been submitted for publication.  A member of the group also published a phenomenology paper related to the LHCb B-physics program.

Work on six additional analyses was undertaken during the award period.  One is close to completion, and some of the others are making good progress.  We will continue working on these projects with support from other awards.

Over the course of three years, 11 undergraduate students participated in our research. Of these, 9 analyzed physics data from LHCb's Run 2 (data collected in the period 2015-2018). Two others worked on detector software for  Run 3 (which started in 2022). One Ph.D. student also did research as part of our group.

We ran QuarkNet Summer Institutes for high school teachers to introduce them to elements of particle physics and related experimental methods. During this award period, we focused on computing technologies that can be used in the high school classroom and on elements of machine learning that relate to experimental particle physics.

The most recent results submitted for publication are illustrated in the two plots that are attached.  These show the invariant mass distributions of candidate neutral B  mesons decaying to  (proton,antiproton,proton,antiproton) final states. The first shows the distribution with selection criteria optimized for studies of B_d  decays and the second with selection criteria optimized for studies of B_s decays.  The accumulation of candidates somewhat below 5300 MeV in the first plot allows us to measure the rate of this decay with better than 20% precision.  The accumulation of candidates somewhat below 5400 MeV in the second plot  strongly suggests that the rate of the B_s decay to the same final state is about the same as the B_s production rate is much smaller than the B_d production rate. Both sets of selection criteria were established before examing the data to avoid potential analyst bias. These are amongst the rarest hadronic B meson decays observed to date, occuring about 2 times per 100000000.
